_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Lion Oil Company A? El Dorado, AR Refinery:  RMP Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Lion Oil Company is committed to operate the El Dorado Refinery in a manner that does not endanger our employees, the environment or the surrounding community.  This commitment is demonstrated by an accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design of new systems, installation of equipment, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the refinery.  It is the company policy to implement reasonable controls to prevent the foreseeable releases of regulated chemicals.  However, in the event that an accidental release occurs, an emergency response plan that designates the roles of individuals has been established to mitigate the impact of the release within practical limits.  


The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Lion Oil Company refinery in El Dorado processes sour crude oil at a production rate of approximately 75,000 barrels per day (42 gals/bls).  The petroleum products include gasoline, diesel, asphalt, coatings, and small quantities of other intermediate products.  The refinery operation produces or uses several regulated substances including propane, butane, hydrogen gas, hydrogen sulfide, and chlorine.  Flammable mixtures make up the majority of these regulated substances.


Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s)

For program level 3 processes, one worst case toxic and one worst case flammable release scenario was reported in the RMP, each of which represents the greatest distance to endpoint for the respective hazard class.  In addition, at least one alternate case scenario was reported for each hazard class.

The toxic worst case and alternate case scenarios both involved the accidental release of chlorine used in treating cooling water at the #6 cooling tower.  This material is stored in 1-ton cylinders and transf

erred on a routine bases by refinery employees.  This particular cooling tower was selected as the release point since it is closest to the property boundary.  The worst case toxic release scenario is a total failure of a chlorine cylinder that would result in a 2000 pound liquid and gaseous release of chlorine causing off-site consequences.  The alternate toxic release scenario is the partial damage to a chlorine cylinder that could result in approximately 1300 pound release causing off-site consequences.  Employee training, PPE and leak repair kits would be mitigating factors to these releases.  

Several release scenarios were evaluated in order to identify appropriate worst and alternate case flammable scenarios.  Of the scenarios evaluated, a catastrophic failure of Tank 536 was identified as the worst case flammable release scenario.  This release could potentially include approximately 3.5 million pounds of flammable hydrocarbon mixture resulting in a vapor cloud explosion causing off-site consequences.  The alternate case flammable release is a failure of the 185 Tank resulting in the release of approximately 300,000 pounds of flammable hydrocarbon mixture.  Such a release could result in a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) and a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) both resulting in off-site consequences.  Employee training, PPE, and both fixed and mobile fire suppression equipment are in place to mitigate the results of these releases.  

Is should be noted that the worst case and alternate case flammable release scenarios presented in this hazard assessment are based on very conservative situations which are unlikely to occur.  A detailed Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) explosion consequence study of the refinery was recently completed by ABS Consulting in January of 2009.  This CFD study evaluated a number of potential explosion scenarios within the process units at the refinery based on detailed, site-specific information.  None of the detailed

scenarios considered in this study were predicted to result in an off-site overpressure of greater than 1-psi.     


General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps

The Lion Oil Company refinery is regulated by the EPA RMP regulations as well as, OSHA PSM regulations.  The following summary addresses the necessary steps taken to comply with these regulations.


Process Safety Information

Lion Oil Company (Lion) has developed the Process Safety Information (PSI) program with the participation and input of our employees from management, supervisory, hourly, and technical positions at the El Dorado refinery.  This program requires that all Lion employees contribute to the collection and retention of PSI that is covered under OSHAA?s PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 (d) (1-3) and EPAA?s RMP Standard, 40 CFR 68.65 (a-d).  Several process units at Lion contain a sufficient amount of highly hazardous chemicals to be covered by the OSHA PSM Standard and the EPA RMP Standard.  Lion recognizes the value of the good engineering and management principles promoted by these regulations and has chosen to apply some elements of the PSI Program to units and areas of the refinery that are not covered by the PSM/RMP regulations.  

Complete and accurate written information concerning process chemistry, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM Program and to a process hazard analysis (PHA).  The information addressed by this program is an essential resource for conducting PHAA?s; employee training, contractor safety, mechanical integrity, procedures, pre-startup safety reviews, management of change, emergency preparedness, and insurance and compliance audits.  Access to PSI information is provided to all employees through LionA?s computerized document control system as well as, a request through the PSM Department or any refinery management staff.  

PSI information and documents are required for all regulatory covered process units and all capita

l projects for major overhauls of existing process units or installation of a new process unit.  It is important to recognize that information is generated throughout the life cycle of a process unit and as such, PSI information is often updated through the MOC or PHA revalidation procedures.  Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response and exposure treatment is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  These documents are available to all employees via a computerized MSDS management system.


Process Hazard Analysis

The refinery processes that contain quantities of regulated substances above threshold quantities are evaluated for potential hazards using the hazop method supplemented by checklists and what-if lists as necessary.  The evaluations are conducted by a team consisting on personnel fimilar with the evaluation methods, refinery operations, maintenance, safety, training, and environmental compliance.  PHA documentation is maintained for the life of the process unit and available to all employees on the computerized document management system (OnBase).  The documentations is reviewed every 5 years and updated as necessary.  Findings and recommendations resulting from a hazop evaluation are addressed in a timely manner.


Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures were developed and are maintained for all processes at the Lion Oil refinery.  These procedures address modes of operations such as initial startup, normal operation, temporary operation, emergency shutdown and operation, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The procedures are reviewed annually and certified as accurate and timely by knowledgeable and experienced operations staff members.


Training

Lion Oil Company implements a comprehensive training program for newly hired operation and maintenance employees.  New applicants are screened by giving preference to those that have completed a WAGE (Workforce Alliance for Growth in the Eco

nomy) certificate program that requires a 12 grade plus 1 semester of college proficiency in basis reading, math, and comprehension, and computer skills.  After being hired, new employees under go extensive written, hands-on and on-the-job training.  Employees that are members of the emergency response team participate in annual training and drills.  Refresher training is required at least every three years and more frequently if necessary.  All training is documented, including the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.


Mechanical Integrity

Lion Oil Company conducts maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  These personnel are also offered specialized training as necessary.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.


Management of Change

Lion Oil Company has a written procedure in place to manage changes in process chemicals, equipment, technology, procedures, and other facility changes to ensure that the proper review and evaluation is conducted before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure proper controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and verify that existing controls are still adequate.  The process safety information associated with the change is updated as necessary.  


Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Lion Oil Company has a written procedure in place to ensure that a review is conducted on any changes or modifications made to a process prior to the restart or initial startup.  The PSSR is designed to check safety controls, procedures, training, design specifications, and installation prior to startup.  The PSSR review team uses checklists

to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR requires field verification of the construction and installation and serves a quality assurance function.



Compliance Audits

Lion Oil Company conducts audits to determine the effectiveness of the procedures and practices of the accident prevention program.  Compliance audits are conducted every 3 years.  The audit team includes personnel and/or contractors familiar with the regulations and audit techniques.  The findings and recommendations developed from the audits are resolved in a timely manner.  The last two most recent audit reports are retained.


Incident Investigation

Lion Oil Company promptly investigates any incident that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in the catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Investigations are conducted to identify the causes of the incident as well as corrective actions to prevent future reoccurrence of the incident.  Findings and recommendations are addressed in a timely manner.  All incident reports are retained for 5 years.


Employee Participation

Lion Oil Company recognizes the valuable knowledge base that experienced employees can contribute to the safe and efficient operation of the processing units.  Employee input is important to the management of the various elements covered in the process safety management system.  Operating and Maintenance employees with working knowledge of the process units and equipment are consulted for input into process hazard analysis, mechanical integrity assurance, and pre-startup reviews.  Operating and Maintenance employees participate in the development and updating of procedures and training materials. Operating and Maintenance employees also participate in the periodic review of procedures and training materials to maintain the accuracy of these documents.  Employees are kept current to the changes within their work area through training, management of changes, pre-startup safety reviews, process hazard analyses, chan

ges in process technology, equipment, emergency procedures, safety procedures, and any other conditions, which could affect their work environment.  This is conducted through the use of training materials, employee meetings, face-to-face communication and materials available in the facilityA?s computer system.  


Contractors

Lion Oil Company uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation is conducted on the past safety performance and current safety program of the contractor.  In addition, refinery safety personnel periodically monitor the onsite safety performance of contractors to ensure they are performing their safety obligations.  Each individual contract employee is required to have a photo identification card that verifies they have completed safety orientation and training through either a regional or local contractor-safety-council.  Contractors are required to complete a site-specific orientation for the refinery prior to starting work.  This orientation includes information regarding site specific hazards and refinery emergency response procedures.


Five-Year Accident History

In the past five years there has been one accidental releases of a regulated chemical resulting in onsite injuries to contract workers.  This injury was not life threatening and did not result in any permanent disability.  In this case the worker was fit to return to work with a few hours.  This accident was:

1.    6/17/2005 A? A contract worker was exposed to a small hydrogen sulfide release while installing a cylinder as part of the repair work on a compressor in the #8 Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel Hydrotreating Unit.  The worker lost consciousness and was given first aid treatment.  He did not suffer any other bodily injury and returned to work before the end of the shift.  

In the past five years there have been no accidents that resulted in an off-site impact to the he

alth and safety of the public or environmental damages.    


Emergency Response Plan

Lion Oil Company maintains a written emergency response plan to respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances.  The plan includes the information necessary to respond to emergency situations including first aid, medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure readiness, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  The plan is reviewed annually and updated in a timely manner as necessary.  This plan is incorporated into the Union County Emergency Operations Plan as part of the Union County LEPC.


Safe Work Practices

Critical safe work policies and procedures have been established by Lion Oil Company.  These include control of entry and access; lockout/tagout, first break of process equipment, hotwork, and confined space work.  These policies and procedures are in the refinery Safety Manual.  This is an evergreen document and is subject to review and modifications as regulations and circumstances change.  Any changes to the safety manual are documented and distributed by the management of change procedure.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The policies and procedures described in the accident prevention program were established by Lion Oil to help prevent equipment failures and human errors from causing a release of a regulated substance.  In addition to the accident prevention program, the refinery has several devices and structures installed to detect, control, and mitigate and accidental release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes at the refinery:

1.    Release Detection
a.    Stationary detectors with alarms for hydrocarbons, ozone, hydrogen sulfide, and hydrogen.
b.    Portable (hand-held and individual personnel) detectors for hydrocarbons, hydrogen sulfide and other gases.

2.    Release Containmen

t and Control
a.    Process relief devices that discharge to a flare system to capture and incinerate hydrocarbon vapors releases.
b.    Scrubbers to neutralize pollutants.
c.    Vapor recovery units.
d.    Double block valves and bleed points on critical equipment.
e.    Manual and automated isolation valves
f.    Automated shutdown systems for critical equipment
g.    Curbs and dikes to contain liquid spills
h.    Redundant equipment and instrumentation (such as backup firewater pumps, backup power supply for process controls, etcA?)
i.    Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of an upset condition (e.g. slop tanks, slop drums, etcA?)

3.    Release Mitigation
a.    Mobile and fixed fire suppression systems
b.    Deluge systems for specific equipment
c.    A trained emergency response team
d.    Personal protective equipment for employees (e.g. flame resistant clothing, respiratory protection equipment, etcA?)
e.    Blast resistant buildings for personnel and control systems
f.    Spill containment equipment and supplies


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The accident prevention program is an evergreen process that must constantly be modified as conditions and regulations change.  Lion currently anticipates the following changes to the program:

1.    Additional blast resistant buildings will be installed for operations personnel
2.    Modifications to occupied buildings to address the risk of breaking window glass, and lose office fixtures, tools, machines, and other objects that could be hurled into occupants in the event of a vapor cloud explosion
3.    Upgrading the computer control systems for some of the process units
4.    Revisions to the fixed fire suppression system to improve performance
5.    The replacement of old process equipment in the #4 Crude Unit
6.    Participate in the development of a local workforce consortium with other local companies and the community college to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of employee and contractor training.
